results.title: Living with disaster 2 : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description:
On the 3rd of June 2010, the residents of Lennox Head, on the North Coast of New South Wales, were preparing for the day ahead when their town was struck by a tornado. Despite having no warning, the tornado managed to pass without any loss of life but left over a hundred homes destroyed and hundreds more without power.

Nine residents of Lennox Head, mostly children, tell their stories about the disaster, revisiting the events of the morning leading up to the tornado and the chaos that followed. They speak frankly about the terror of the moment it hit and the way that day’s events have affected them since.

results.title: Jeff Lindsay in conversation with Sue Turnbull: Dark Tales, Serial Archetypes [web excerpt]
results.creator_credit: David Meagher, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Jeff Lindsay, author and creator of our favourite serial killer ‘Dexter’, is joined in conversation with Professor Sue Turnbull, as they explore the renaissance of macabre fairytales in popular culture.

Jeff Lindsay and Sue Turnbull touch on many of the themes covered in the ‘Fairytales Re-imagined’ symposium, providing a fascinatingly insightful discussion centred around the development of fairy tale motifs in popular culture. In this web excerpt, Lindsay focuses on cannibalism, the theme of his most recent installment ‘Dexter is delicious’. He explores it’s origins in fairy tales and the proliferation of cannibalism through online forums.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Mansfield Shire
results.brief_description: ‘ACMI in the regions: stories from Mansfield Shire’ takes a look at the towns of Mansfield, Tolmie and Jamieson, located in north-eastern Victoria. Interviews with the locals provide a sense of the rich history of these towns and the lifeblood that keeps them thriving.

results.title: Ningla A-Na
results.brief_description: For the first time in 200 years of white domination, Aboriginal people confronted the government at a national level – and in the words of poet, author and campaigner for Indigenous land rights Roberta “Bobbi” Sykes, achieved “a political victory”. Framed within an international human rights context, ‘Ningla A-Na’ (Hungry for Land) uses television news coverage of the clash between protesters and police at the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in 1972 to great effect, showing how the event was portrayed both nationally and internationally. Interviews with Dr Fred Hollows, Shirley Smith (Mum Shirl), Bob Maza, Carol Johnson and Paul Coe contextualise the issues advocated by the Black movement. This film gives voice to the most talented and effective Indigenous activists in the country at the time. Source: Australian Screen

results.title: Legacy : a promise for the future : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Six members of Melbourne Legacy give their individual stories of how they got into contact with Legacy. Whether they are survivors of war, employees of Legacy or the children of soldiers, Legacy manages make a significant impression on the lives of its members and provides inspiration for future generations.

results.title: Experience the unknown
results.creator_credit: Valentina Zingg, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Overwhelmed by choice, Valentina Zingg decides to journey to a land very different to Switzerland. While this hot, dry land helps her gain perspective, there is still something missing…

results.title: May's story
results.creator_credit: Sue Freeth, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: In 1895, at the age of 24, May sailed to Japan and dedicated her life to caring for the children in the villages. Sue Freeth, with the help of some of May’s ex-students, traces the path walked by May, and in doing so comes closer to understanding the life of this amazing woman.

results.title: Bus people
results.creator_credit: Nicole Bloom, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When you’re poor, there’s nothing as important as finding food. Nicole Bloom movingly recalls her distressing time on the streets, amongst the poor people of Melbourne, when riding on the bus is a luxury.
